perturbation.original_text: Section 1.6 Integrity shall be deemed to be an independent contractor and, except as specifically provided or authorized herein, shall have no authority to act for or represent the Fund. Integrity will act only on its own behalf as principal should it choose to enter into selling agreements with selected dealers or others.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 1.6 Integrity shall be deemed to be an employee and, except as specifically provided or authorized herein, shall have no authority to act for or represent the Fund. Integrity will act only on its own behalf as principal should it choose to enter into selling agreements with selected dealers or others.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'independent contractor' to 'employee' creates a conflict. The contract later treats Integrity as an independent entity, managing its own expenses and activities. Designating them as an 'employee' can blur the lines of liability and control, conflicting with the intended operational framework.
perturbation.contradicted_law: IRS guidelines on employee vs. independent contractor classification
perturbation.law_explanation: The IRS has specific guidelines for determining whether someone is an employee or an independent contractor. Factors such as control over work, financial investment, and the relationship of the parties are considered. This modification contradicts these established criteria by classifying Integrity as an 'employee' while simultaneously granting them independent control over their operations, potentially leading to misclassification under tax law.

perturbation.original_text: Section 7.1 This Agreement shall continue until January 18, 2022, and thereafter shall continue automatically for successive annual periods ending on January 18th of each year, provided such continuance is specifically approved at least annually by (a) the Fund's Board of Trustees and (b) a vote of a majority (as defined in the 1940 Act) of the Fund's Trustees who are not interested persons (as defined in the 1940 Act) of the Fund and who have no direct or indirect financial interest in the operation of the Plan, in this Agreement, or any agreement related to the Plan (the "Qualified Trustees"), by vote cast in person at a meeting called for the purpose of voting on such approval.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 7.1 This Agreement shall continue until January 18, 2022, and thereafter shall continue automatically for successive annual periods ending on January 18th of each year, regardless of any approval by (a) the Fund's Board of Trustees and (b) a vote of a majority (as defined in the 1940 Act) of the Fund's Trustees who are not interested persons (as defined in the 1940 Act) of the Fund and who have no direct or indirect financial interest in the operation of the Plan, in this Agreement, or any agreement related to the Plan (the "Qualified Trustees"), by vote cast in person at a meeting called for the purpose of voting on such approval.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the requirement for annual approval from the Board of Trustees directly contradicts the Investment Company Act of 1940, which mandates specific governance and oversight for investment company agreements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Section 15(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940
perturbation.law_citation: 15 U.S. Code ยง 80a-15 - Contracts of advisers and underwriters
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 15(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 requires that the board of directors, including a majority of independent directors, specifically approve the continuation of contracts such as distribution agreements. Removing the approval requirement violates this section of the act, making the automatic renewal potentially illegal and unenforceable.

perturbation.original_text: Section 8.3 This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Kansas.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 8.3 This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the People's Republic of China.
perturbation.explanation: Specifying the laws of The People's Republic of China to govern a contract between two US-based entities (Integrity Short Term Government Fund in Delaware and Integrity Funds Distributor, LLC) could be problematic. Unless there's a very specific and compelling reason, US courts may find this choice-of-law clause unenforceable, particularly if it violates fundamental principles of US law or public policy.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Enforceability of choice-of-law clauses in contracts
perturbation.law_citation: Restatement (Second) of Conflict of Laws ยง 187
perturbation.law_explanation: The Restatement (Second) of Conflict of Laws ยง 187 outlines the principles governing the enforceability of choice-of-law clauses. While parties are generally free to choose the law governing their contract, a court may not enforce the chosen law if it violates a fundamental policy of a state which has a materially greater interest than the chosen state in the determination of the particular issue. Here, using Chinese law to govern the contract between two US entities could violate fundamental US securities and investment regulations, making the choice-of-law clause unenforceable.
